Can this happen during startup if the remote config overrides local settings?
Either case, I believe the HYBRID strategy is not as safe as it relies on reflection, which can wake up hidden daemons.
I recall a scenario where some JDBC driver compiled with one JDBC specification version, was used in an environment that contained an older JDBC version. While that was never a problem, as the incompatible methods were never used and the JVM did method-granularity-lazy class linkage, the usage of getDeclaredMethods surfaced this incompatibility as it caused an attempt to resolve all methods.

Can this happen during startup if the remote config overrides local settings?

yes, that's possible

the usage of getDeclaredMethods surfaced this incompatibility as it caused an attempt to resolve all methods

What is the consequence of that? Can't we just ignore the linkage errors?
Good question, I am not sure how the JVM would treat a class that is already loaded and partly linked and suddenly fails linkage...

Can this happen during startup if the remote config overrides local settings?

yes, that's possible

In this case reflection may be used on startup
I guess it should be relatively safe to ignore them. However, we'd lose the ability to instrument those classes. Changing to POOL_ONLY for now.

Make the initInstrumentation() method synchronized as well, as it registers listeners that can be called concurrently (assuming that net.bytebuddy.agent.builder.AgentBuilder#installOn and net.bytebuddy.agent.builder.AgentBuilder#patchOnByteBuddyAgent should not be invoked concurrently)
Byte Buddy is batching by default (via RedefinitionStrategy.BatchAllocator.ForTotal.INSTANCE)
RedefinitionStrategy.BatchAllocator.ForTotal.INSTANCE means it is not batching, it includes all in one batch
I see what you mean now. Which batch size would you propose? Should we sleep between batches? Or should we just start with a single batch?

I would say it makes sense to use a single batch on startup when the instrumentations are applied through premain or programmatic attach and use batches when applied through agentmain or when re-instrumenting.

should we just start with a single batch?

The reason I am suggesting it in this PR is because of the introduction of re-instrumentation, but if you have a reason to merge this quickly, it can be done in a separate PR. I think that if it is a matter of small effort- it worth it. Your call.

Which batch size would you propose?

Well, as you imagine, it would just be random anyways 🙂 . The main idea is not to cause a long degradation in app performance. From the top of my head- 100 per batch.

Should we sleep between batches?

Certainly, . We can use net.bytebuddy.agent.builder.AgentBuilder.RedefinitionStrategy.Listener.Pausing for that.
traceMethods and disabledInstrumentations are tested, but seems that dynamically changing instrument is not tested.
